And for lack of a better word philosophically, are how I approached this project

There was no “oh this is different/bigger so I’m gonna change how I do things”, the opposite is true. I doubled down and had to

So if you’ve read what I say here you can guess the signal chain, and what I did to mixes before I mastered. And more importantly if you’ve met with some of what I’ve written here you’ll have a good sense of *why* I did what I did 

But most of all I hope that you have a sense of the scale of Mastering’s contribution to a project like this. Let’s keep things in proportion and acknowledge the relative scale of invention and artistry in the songs, performances and production and what I did at the end

Not feigning humility, or diminishing my work. Just re stating why this work is compelling, and it’s not equilibrium

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
If I was in charge of newcomer's career in Mastering based on everything I've learned I would say

1) Focus 100% of early efforts on getting the best speaker/room combo you can muster in place (forget all other gear for now except a functioning computer). Note I didn't say "most expensive"

2) Next spend as much time as possible listening with the best listeners you can get access to (other engineers, music fans, kids)

3) Ignore almost everything you read and watch on the internet about the topic of Mastering 

4) RIngfence your time developing and understanding techniques away from when you are actually working on music

5) Maximize your availibilty to the music (keep distractions, overheads, gear envy, fear etc to a minimum)

6) Now listen as widely as you can, to every genre - listen for details, listen like a fan, zoom in, zoom out, zoom in again

7) Love everything you touch. You don't have to like it, but you've gotta love it. Love is a quality of attention. Attend to the music with generosity, as you would a child, or grandma, or a precious butterfly

author: Rollmottle
content:
Every streaming service has a different number at which they will do normalization. If you are above that number and the user has normalization enabled, the service will turn the music down to match that number.

The immediate problems baked in:
1. Every service works differently. One cannot confidently shoot at a target that doesn’t really exist. So, just master the material for the material.
2. Not every user has normalization turned on. Thus, the material will be arbitrarily quiet next to other material that isn’t mastered to the target. So, just master the material for the material.
3. Not everybody consumes through streaming. Outside of a platform, the material needs to stand on its own. So, just master the material for the material.
4. Lots of modern music benefits sonically from being pushed into a limiter. Mastering below that short changes the material. So, just master the material for the material.

author: Berlin
content:
Yes and a few reasons why.

Firstly, I just didn’t have the time anymore to real time bounce - especially when it came to multiple deliverables (Main, ACA, INST, TV, Clean, etc).

And Secondly going out and back in opens more opportunity for unintended changes to happen to the master, like LR Balance or dropped samples - you have to watch for that stuff like a hawk - so QC time increases as well keeping an eye out. More time spent bouncing and QCing, means less time available for more work and even less personal time.

Thirdly, I learned pretty quickly that people really love their mixes and the less I do to a track and the more I get out of the way to finish it, the happier everyone is. Having “fun” with gear (to me) was just me putting myself/ego into the equation and truthfully I just needed to get out of the way.

Fitter, Happier, More Productive.

author: Rollmottle
content:
Been trying to think of a way in to the question about what I did without being completely frustrating or giving a list of moves that don't mean anything outside of the context of being in my chair, hearing what and how I hear.

This process for this song is like any other...listen for what the song needs and act accordingly. That's the frustrating answer but it's also true. What did you do? "I mastered it." lol

But I know that's not what you're asking. For a track like this, I'm primarily focused on the vocal and how it's sitting and feeling. The vocal performance is incredibly dynamic and intimate. This one had some ringy stuff through 2.5k and in the upper mid range that I felt was detracting from the "fireside" intimacy. The goal was to take off some of the edge without stepping on the presence. That was a combo of RX and EQ. 

On this song, I did an analog pass because I am usually able to manage to get the balance of presence and de-edge I'm looking for very quickly. Since time was of the essence here, that was the move. Couple of moves on Equilibrium digitally before the Gyraf and Porter Grinder in the analog chain. The "trickiest" thing I did here was flip the Porter Grinder into M/S to bring the vocal closer into the center (by cutting!) and to push the mellotron and atmospherics to the sides (by boosting). All very subtle stuff.

So, there were some moves here, but the moves were all in service of the feeling the song was telling me it needed. We talk a lot about monitoring here. When you can connect to the song and walk around inside of it, it's much easier to know what you need to do (or not to do) to bring it to life.

content: Ruairi fishing for deep cuts! The best experience I ever had was over a decade ago. Having spent a considerable chunk of time recording an album for & with my best friend -- we asked Eric Valentine to master the record and he said yes. He sized up the mixes in no time, told me the strengths, the weaknesses, even sent me into the other room to re-print versions slightly quieter, fix this pop here, maybe put the guitar solo up here. author: hebakadry
content: As far as the Atmos vs Vinyl debate…vinyl has an amazing organic culture that has spanned decades especially in the electronic and techno scene…unlike Atmos…a multi channel film format shoehorned by a bunch of corporations to sell their shitty proprietary headphones.  If one more person tries to shill the “stereo is vintage” debate, I will gouge them in the eyes.   Stereo rules…and it’s withstood all the changes this industry has seen because it’s FREE when Alan Blumlien's patent ran out and everyone eventually adopted it…it was not proprietary…and asking the consumer to add one speaker was not a huge ask.  Whereas now, with Atmos…I dunno…it’s depressing.  It's riddled with problems including their horrible horrible binaural algorithm which will continue to change and possibly improve while the engineers that make the records will have absolutely no say in said changes.  I think I wouldn't have had a problem with Atmos if they didn't force the binaural format because it takes the craft out of the medium and you end up spending half the time trying to remotely match the stereo version.  People are making money off of it, but it’s just NOT the artist.  I haven’t met a single artist that was actually excited about Atmos.  Like truly excited about it.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: It has become fashionable to post online about targeting -14LUFS or so, but in my opinion, if you care about sounding approximately as loud as other artists, and until loudness normalization improves and becomes universally implemented, that is mostly well-meaning internet chatter, not good practical advice. My advice is to make one digital master that sounds good, is not overly crushed for loudness, and use it for everything. Let the various streaming sites normalize it as they wish. It will still sound just as good. Normalization does no harm to the audio - it's merely a playback volume setting.
